content.definition: A non-invasive measurement of the pressure required to restore skin blood flow after occlusion, typically using laser Doppler technology. SPP measures microcirculatory perfusion at the skin level and is particularly useful for predicting wound healing potential in patients with diabetes and/or arterial disease.

principle: Occlusive cuff placed over measurement site
Slow deflation while monitoring laser Doppler signal
SPP = pressure at which skin blood flow returns
what_it_measures: Reflects true tissue perfusion rather than conduit flow

equipment: Pressure cuff (small, for toe or forefoot)
sites: Can be measured near wound margin
measurement: Place cuff proximal to measurement site
Slowly deflate while monitoring laser Doppler signal
Record pressure at return of skin blood flow

over_abi_tbi: Not affected by medial arterial calcification
Useful in diabetics with falsely elevated ABI
over_tcpo2: Can measure in presence of edema

limitations: May be affected by cellulitis or severe edema

comparison_with_other_tests.abi: Measures conduit pressure; falsely elevated with calcification
comparison_with_other_tests.tbi: Measures toe pressure; better than ABI but still affected by calcification
comparison_with_other_tests.tcpo2: Measures tissue oxygenation; affected by oxygen delivery and temperature
comparison_with_other_tests.spp: Measures microcirculatory perfusion; most reliable for wound healing prediction

learning_objectives: Understand the principle of SPP measurement
Know the thresholds for wound healing prediction
Compare SPP to other perfusion tests
clinical_pearls: SPP <30 mmHg = poor healing - consider revascularization
Advantage over ABI/TBI: NOT affected by calcification
Particularly useful in diabetics with medial calcinosis
Can measure at or near wound site for localized assessment
